match.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: an organized sports event between two teams or people
match.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: It’s our last match of the season.
They’re preparing for a big (=important) match tomorrow.
McClaire’s goal earned him the title of man of the match (=the person in a team who plays best).
Good teams win their home matches.
the match between Nigeria and Ireland
match.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: a small wooden or paper stick with a special substance at the top, that you use to light a fire, cigarette etc
match.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: Don’t let your children play with matches.
I tore up the letter and put a match to it  (=made it burn, using a match).
Peg struck a match and lit the candle.
match.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: something that is the same colour or pattern as something else, or looks attractive with it
match.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: That shirt’s a perfect match for your blue skirt.
match.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: someone who is much stronger, cleverer etc than their opponent
match.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: Carlos was no match for the champion.
This time you’ve met your match, Adam Burns! I’m not giving up without a fight!
Guerrilla tactics proved more than a match for the Soviet military machine.
match.translation[0].definitions[4].defi: a marriage or two people who are married
match.translation[0].definitions[4].note: a match made in heaven (=a marriage of two people who are exactly right for each other)
match.translation[0].definitions[4].exam: Claire made a good match (=married someone suitable).
match.translation[0].definitions[5].defi: a situation in which something is suitable for something else, so that the two things work together successfully
match.translation[0].definitions[5].exam: We need to establish a match between students’ needs and teaching methods.
match.translation[0].note_box[0].section: go to a match
I love going to football matches.
watch a match
I watched the match on TV.
play a match
We played the match in heavy rain.
lose a match
They lost the match, despite playing very well.
win a match
Do you think we'll win our next match?
draw a match
United have drawn their last two matches.
have a match
Do we have a match on Sunday?
postpone a match
Our first match was postponed because of bad weather.
miss a match
He missed two matches because of an ankle injury.
level the match
Woods won the last two holes to level the match.
clinch the match
Ronaldo clinched the match with a brilliant goal.
referee a match
The matches are refereed by the children's parents.
a match kicks off
The match kicks off at 3.30 pm.
ADJECTIVES/NOUN + match
great/brilliant
We're sure it's going to be another great match.
exciting
The match could not have been more exciting.
thrilling
There were some thrilling matches at Wimbledon this year.
At this stage of the competition, every match is tough.
Germany won the match, although it was close.
an important/crucial match
Luckily, all their players are fit for such an important match.
a big match
Are you going to watch the big match on TV?
a football/rugby/tennis etc match
There was a rugby match going on on the school field.
a home match
They have won their last five home matches.
an away match
This is their last away match of the season.
a live match
There is a live match on TV every Wednesday evening.
a friendly match
Fitness is still important in friendly matches.
a qualifying match
They won all their qualifying matches.
a semi-final match
Spain beat Russia in their semi-final match last night.
phrase
man of the match
Henri was named man of the match.
match.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: if one thing matches another, or if two things match, they look attractive together because they are a similar colour, pattern etc
match.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: We painted the cabinets green to match the rug.
Do you think this outfit matches?
a beech dining table with four chairs to match  (=chairs that match it)
match.translation[1].definitions[0].note: Her bag matched with her shoes
Her bag matched to her shoes
match.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: two things that match look the same because they are a pair
match.translation[1].definitions[2].defi: if two things match, or if one matches the other, there is no important difference between them
match.translation[1].definitions[2].exam: The suspect matched the descriptions provided by witnesses.
Their actions do not match their words.
The copy closely matches the original.
match.translation[1].definitions[3].defi: to be suitable for a particular person, thing, or situation
match.translation[1].definitions[3].exam: Teaching materials should match individual students’ needs.
We’ll help you find a home that will match your requirements.
match.translation[1].definitions[4].defi: to put two people or things together that are similar to or somehow connected with each other
match.translation[1].definitions[4].exam: Can you name the animals and match them to the correct countries?
All checked-in baggage must be matched with a passenger travelling on the aircraft.
match.translation[1].definitions[5].defi: to be equal to something in value, size, or quality
match.translation[1].definitions[5].exam: His strength is matched by his intelligence.
Few cities in Europe can match the cultural richness of Berlin.
Fancy designer labels tend to come with fancy price tags to match.
The two candidates are fairly evenly matched.
match.translation[1].definitions[6].defi: to make something equal to something else
match.translation[1].definitions[6].exam: Lindsey matched her steps to those of the other girl as they walked.
an attempt to match financial resources to need
match.translation[1].definitions[7].defi: to give a sum of money that is equal to a sum given by someone else
match.translation[1].definitions[7].exam: The government has promised to match any private donations to the earthquake fund.
match.translation[1].definitions[8].defi: if you are matched against someone else in a game or competition, you are competing against them
match.translation[1].definitions[8].exam: Federer was matched against Nadal in the final.
match.translation[1].definitions[8].note: Match is usually passive in this meaning
match.translation[1].note_box[0].section: if something matches something else, they look good together because they are very similar in colour or style
a black suit with a handbag and shoes to match
to look good with something else – Go with is very common in everyday English
Do you think that blue wallpaper will go with the carpet?
if two things go together, they look good when they are worn or seen with each other. Go together is very common in everyday English
That jacket and skirt don’t really go together.
The blue and the yellow go together well.
if a piece of clothing or a colour  complements  something, it makes it look more attractive
A simple string of pearls will complement any outfit.
if clothes, decorations etc are well or perfectly coordinated, they look good together because they have similar colours and styles
Her outfits are always perfectly coordinated.
